Exercise

Which of the following mathematical equations is equivalent to Newton's Law of Cooling? First, find an expression for the rate of cooling, and an expression for the difference between the liquid's temperature and that of the  environment. Note that \(k\) is a positive constant.

generalfeedback.text: You should obtain \({\mathrm{d}\theta\over \mathrm{d}t}\propto (\theta-\theta_\text{s})\) or, equivalently: \({\mathrm{d}\theta\over \mathrm{d}t}=-k(\theta-\theta_\text{s})\).  \(k\) is a positive constant of proportion and the negative sign is present because (\(\theta-\theta_\text{s}\)) is positive, whereas \({\mathrm{d}\theta\over \mathrm{d}t}\) must be negative, since \(\theta\) decreases with time. The units of \(k\) are s\(^{-1}\). The accompanying condition is \(\theta=\theta_0\) at \(t=0\) which simply states the temperature of the liquid when the cooling begins.
